      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic">Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">Occupation of the Baltic states</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states_under_Soviet_rule_(1944%E2%80%931991)" title="Baltic states under Soviet rule (1944–1991)">Baltic states under Soviet rule (1944–1991)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Thousands of Estonians opposing the second Soviet occupation joined a guerrilla movement known as <a href="/wiki/Forest_Brothers" title="Forest Brothers">Forest Brothers</a>. The armed resistance was heaviest in the first few years after the war, but Soviet authorities gradually wore it down through attrition, and resistance effectively ceased to exist in the mid-1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> The Soviets initiated a <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Collectivization in the Soviet Union">policy of collectivisation</a>, but as peasants remained opposed to it a campaign of terror was unleashed. In March 1949 about 20,000 Estonians <a href="/wiki/Operation_Priboi" title="Operation Priboi">were deported</a> to Siberia. Collectivization was fully completed soon afterwards.<sup id="cite_ref-Miljan110_117-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Miljan110-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Soviet Union began <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a>, with hundreds of thousands of <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Estonia" title="Russians in Estonia">Russians</a> and people of other <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> nationalities being induced to settle in Estonia, which eventually threatened to turn Estonians into a minority in their own land.<sup id="cite_ref-Taagepera97_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taagepera97-135">[135]</a></sup> In 1945 Estonians formed 97% of the population, but by 1989 their share of the population had fallen to 62%.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Economically, heavy industry was strongly prioritised, but this did not improve the well-being of the local population, and caused massive environmental damage through pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Living standards under the Soviet occupation kept falling further behind nearby independent Finland.<sup id="cite_ref-Taagepera97_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taagepera97-135">[135]</a></sup> The country was heavily militarised, with closed military areas covering 2% of territory.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> Islands and most of the coastal areas were turned into a restricted border zone which required a special permit for entry.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, and the majority of other Western countries <a href="/wiki/Stimson_Doctrine" title="Stimson Doctrine">considered</a> the annexation of Estonia by the Soviet Union illegal.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/State_continuity_of_the_Baltic_states" title="State continuity of the Baltic states">Legal continuity</a> of the Estonian state was preserved through the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_government-in-exile" title="Estonian government-in-exile">government-in-exile</a> and the Estonian <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Diplomatic_Service_(1940%E2%80%9391)" title="Estonian Diplomatic Service (1940–91)">diplomatic representatives</a> which Western governments continued to recognise.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Restoration_of_independence">Restoration of independence</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Restoration of independence">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">Singing Revolution</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Balti_kett_22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Balti_kett_22.jpg/220px-Balti_kett_22.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Balti_kett_22.jpg/330px-Balti_kett_22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Balti_kett_22.jpg/440px-Balti_kett_22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1499" data-file-height="1007"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Balti_kett_22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">Baltic Way</a> in <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic">Estonian S.S.R.</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The introduction of <a href="/wiki/Perestroika" title="Perestroika">perestroika</a> in 1987 made political activity possible again, starting an independence restoration process known as the <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">Singing Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> The environmental <a href="/wiki/Phosphorite_War" title="Phosphorite War">Phosphorite War</a> campaign became the first major protest movement against the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Government of the Soviet Union">central government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> In 1988, new political movements appeared, such as the <a href="/wiki/Popular_Front_of_Estonia" title="Popular Front of Estonia">Popular Front of Estonia</a>, which came to represent the moderate wing in the independence movement, and the more radical <a href="/wiki/Estonian_National_Independence_Party" title="Estonian National Independence Party">Estonian National Independence Party</a>, which was the first non-communist party in the Soviet Union and demanded full restoration of independence.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Reformist <a href="/wiki/Vaino_V%C3%A4ljas" title="Vaino Väljas">Vaino Väljas</a> became the first secretary of the Estonian Communist Party, and under his leadership on 16 November 1988, the Estonian <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Soviet" title="Supreme Soviet">Supreme Soviet</a> issued the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Sovereignty_Declaration" title="Estonian Sovereignty Declaration">Sovereignty Declaration</a>, asserting the primacy of Estonian laws over Union laws. Over the next two years, almost all other <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">Soviet Republics</a> followed the Estonian lead, issuing similar declarations.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> On 23 August 1989, about 2&nbsp;million Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians participated in a mass demonstration, forming the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">Baltic Way</a> human chain across the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">three republics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> In 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Estonia" title="Congress of Estonia">Congress of Estonia</a> was formed as the representative body of Estonian citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> In March 1991, a <a href="/wiki/1991_Estonian_independence_referendum" title="1991 Estonian independence referendum">referendum was held</a> where 78.4% of voters supported independence, and during the <a href="/wiki/1991_Soviet_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt">coup attempt in Moscow</a>, Estonia <a href="/wiki/Estonian_restoration_of_Independence" class="mw-redirect" title="Estonian restoration of Independence">declared restoration of independence</a> on 20 August,<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> which is now an <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Estonia" title="Public holidays in Estonia">Estonian national holiday</a> known as the Day of Restoration of Independence.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Soviet authorities recognised Estonian independence on 6 September, and on 17 September Estonia was admitted into the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dillon164_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dillon164-152">[152]</a></sup> The last units of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_army" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian army">Russian army</a> left Estonia in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1992 radical economic reforms were launched for switching over to a market economy, including privatisation and currency reform.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> Estonia has been a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> since 13 November 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> Estonian foreign policy since independence has been oriented toward <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">the West</a>, and in 2004 Estonia joined both the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>On 9 December 2010, Estonia became a member of <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> On 1 January 2011, Estonia joined the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> and adopted the EU single currency as the first former Soviet Union state.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Estonia was elected as a member of the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security council">UN Security Council</a> 2020–21.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Territorial_history_timeline">Territorial history timeline</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Territorial history timeline">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <table style="border:0px background-color:#f7f8ff; padding:0px;" align="center"> 
        <tbody>
         <tr> 
          <td> 
           <div class="timeline-wrapper">
            <map name="timeline_e8617d2a6d1885183816c0cd9b273425"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Livonian_Confederation" coords="278,59,437,80" title="Livonian Confederation" alt="Livonian Confederation"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Terra_Mariana" coords="96,86,205,107" title="Terra Mariana" alt="Terra Mariana"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" coords="726,120,828,141" title="Estonian SSR" alt="Estonian SSR"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Livonia_(1721%E2%80%931917)" coords="538,127,668,147" title="Duchy of Livonia (1721–1917)" alt="Duchy of Livonia (1721–1917)"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Livonia_(1629%E2%80%931721)" coords="455,127,541,147" title="Duchy of Livonia (1629–1721)" alt="Duchy of Livonia (1629–1721)"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Livonia_(1561%E2%80%931621)" coords="404,127,490,147" title="Duchy of Livonia (1561–1621)" alt="Duchy of Livonia (1561–1621)"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Estonia_(1721%E2%80%931917)" coords="538,80,668,100" title="Duchy of Estonia (1721–1917)" alt="Duchy of Estonia (1721–1917)"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Estonia_(1561%E2%80%931721)" coords="410,80,541,100" title="Duchy of Estonia (1561–1721)" alt="Duchy of Estonia (1561–1721)"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Danish_Estonia" coords="399,39,463,60" title="Danish Estonia" alt="Danish Estonia"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Danish_Estonia" coords="117,39,192,60" title="Danish Estonia" alt="Danish Estonia"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Estonia" coords="707,167,848,188" title="Estonia" alt="Estonia"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Estonia" coords="8,46,128,67" title="Ancient Estonia" alt="Ancient Estonia"><area shape="rect" href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia" coords="297,12,536,36" title="History of Estonia" alt="History of Estonia"></map>
            <img usemap="#timeline_e8617d2a6d1885183816c0cd9b273425" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/e8617d2a6d1885183816c0cd9b273425.png">
           </div> </td>
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> 
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Estonia" title="Geography of Estonia">Geography of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Estonia_relief_map_(2005-2017).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png/220px-Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png/330px-Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png/440px-Estonia_relief_map_%282005-2017%29.png 2x" data-file-width="833" data-file-height="696"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Estonia_relief_map_(2005-2017).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of Estonia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia lies on the eastern shores of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> immediately across the Gulf of Finland, on the level northwestern part of the rising <a href="/wiki/East_European_platform" class="mw-redirect" title="East European platform">East European platform</a> between 57.3° and 59.5°&nbsp;N and 21.5° and 28.1°&nbsp;E. Average elevation reaches only 50 metres (164&nbsp;ft) and the country's highest point is the <a href="/wiki/Suur_Munam%C3%A4gi" title="Suur Munamägi">Suur Munamägi</a> in the southeast at 318 metres (1,043&nbsp;ft). There is 3,794 kilometres (2,357&nbsp;mi) of coastline marked by numerous bays, straits, and inlets. Estonia's number of islands and islets in the Baltic Sea is estimated at some 2,222, and the country has 2,355 including those in lakes. Two of them are large enough to constitute separate counties: <a href="/wiki/Saaremaa" title="Saaremaa">Saaremaa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">Hiiumaa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-worldinfo_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldinfo-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-worldinfoEstonia_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldinfoEstonia-161">[161]</a></sup> A small, recent cluster of meteorite craters, the largest of which is called <a href="/wiki/Kaali_crater" title="Kaali crater">Kaali</a> is found on Saaremaa, Estonia. </p>
      <p>Estonia has over <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of lakes in Estonia">1,400 lakes</a>. Most are very small, with the largest, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">Lake Peipus</a>, being 3,555&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,373&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). There are many rivers in the country. The longest of them are Võhandu (162&nbsp;km or 101&nbsp;mi), Pärnu (144&nbsp;km or 89&nbsp;mi), and Põltsamaa (135&nbsp;km or 84&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-worldinfo_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldinfo-160">[160]</a></sup> Estonia has numerous <a href="/wiki/Fen" title="Fen">fens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bogs" class="mw-redirect" title="Bogs">bogs</a>. Forest land covers 50% of Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-timber_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timber-162">[162]</a></sup> The most common tree species are pine, spruce and birch.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">Phytogeographically</a>, Estonia is shared between the Central European and Eastern European provinces of the <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">Circumboreal Region</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">WWF</a>, the territory of Estonia belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sarmatic_mixed_forests" title="Sarmatic mixed forests">Sarmatic mixed forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-164">[164]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Estonia" title="Climate of Estonia">Climate of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia is situated in the northern part of the <a href="/wiki/Temperate" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperate">temperate climate zone</a> and in the transition zone between <a href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Maritime climate">maritime</a> and <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification#Group_D:_Continental/microthermal_climates" title="Köppen climate classification">continental climate</a>. The climate is more continental in the eastern part of the country and more maritime in the western part, especially on the islands. Estonia has four seasons of near-equal length. Average temperatures range from 17.8&nbsp;°C (64.0&nbsp;°F) on the islands to 18.4&nbsp;°C (65.1&nbsp;°F) inland in July, the warmest month, and from −1.4&nbsp;°C (29.5&nbsp;°F) on the islands to −5.3&nbsp;°C (22.5&nbsp;°F) inland in February, the coldest month. The average annual temperature in Estonia is 6.4&nbsp;°C (43.5&nbsp;°F). <sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Annual average precipitation is 662 mm.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> The average for the year is 1829.6 hours of sunshine.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> The duration of sunshine is highest in coastal areas and lowest inland in northern Estonia. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Estonia" title="Fauna of Estonia">Fauna of Estonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Estonia" title="Protected areas of Estonia">Protected areas of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Landsvale.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Landsvale.jpg/220px-Landsvale.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Landsvale.jpg/330px-Landsvale.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Landsvale.jpg/440px-Landsvale.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Landsvale.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Barn_swallow" title="Barn swallow">barn swallow</a> (<i>H. r. rustica</i>) is the national bird of Estonia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many species extinct in most of the European countries can be still found in Estonia. Mammals present in Estonia include the <a href="/wiki/Grey_wolf" class="mw-redirect" title="Grey wolf">grey wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">lynx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_badger" title="European badger">badger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_beaver" class="mw-redirect" title="European beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_otter" title="Eurasian otter">otter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grey_seal" title="Grey seal">grey seal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ringed_seal" title="Ringed seal">ringed seal</a>. Critically endangered <a href="/wiki/European_mink" title="European mink">European mink</a> has been successfully reintroduced to the island of <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">Hiiumaa</a>, and the rare <a href="/wiki/Siberian_flying_squirrel" title="Siberian flying squirrel">Siberian flying squirrel</a> is present in east Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Introduced species, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sika_deer" title="Sika deer">sika deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raccoon_dog" title="Raccoon dog">raccoon dog</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muskrat" title="Muskrat">muskrat</a>, can now be found throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Over 300 bird species have been found in Estonia, including the <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_eagle" title="White-tailed eagle">white-tailed eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lesser_spotted_eagle" title="Lesser spotted eagle">lesser spotted eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">golden eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_capercaillie" title="Western capercaillie">western capercaillie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Stork" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Stork">black</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">white stork</a>, numerous species of <a href="/wiki/Owls" class="mw-redirect" title="Owls">owls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wader" title="Wader">waders</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geese" class="mw-redirect" title="Geese">geese</a> and many others.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Barn_swallow" title="Barn swallow">barn swallow</a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_bird" class="mw-redirect" title="National bird">national bird</a> of Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Estonia" title="Protected areas of Estonia">Protected areas</a> cover 18% of Estonian land and 26% of its sea territory. There are 6 national parks, 159 nature reserves, and many other protection areas.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> It had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 3.05/10, ranking it 152nd globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-174">[174]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As a result of loss of biodiversity, there are around 100,000 breeding pairs of birds less in Estonia than in previous years. Approximately half of Estonia's territory is covered with forests, but in fact, only around one-two per cent of it can be considered truly natural old-growth forests – the rest is young and managed.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Across Estonia, between 2001 and 2019, <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a> areas lost more than 15,000 hectares (37,000 acres) of forest cover. The last five years account for 80% of that loss. Further alterations to rules in other Estonian national parks are planned. This practice is also being pursued by RMK,<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> the state forest management company, which manages around half of Estonian forests.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Estonia" title="Politics of Estonia">Politics of Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Estonia" title="List of political parties in Estonia">List of political parties in Estonia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Estonia" title="Elections in Estonia">Elections in Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:245px;max-width:245px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:126px;max-width:126px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/124px-Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="124" height="168" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/186px-Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/248px-Kersti_Kaljulaid_-_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2380" data-file-height="3226"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Kersti_Kaljulaid" title="Kersti Kaljulaid">Kersti Kaljulaid</a>
           <br><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">President</a><br>since 2016</small>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:115px;max-width:115px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg/113px-RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg" decoding="async" width="113" height="167" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg/170px-RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg/226px-RE_Kaja_Kallas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1228" data-file-height="1818"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Kaja_Kallas" title="Kaja Kallas">Kaja Kallas</a>
           <br><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Estonia" title="Prime Minister of Estonia">Prime Minister</a><br>since 2021</small>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia is a unitary <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>. The unicameral parliament <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">Riigikogu</a> serves as the legislative and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">the government</a> as the executive.<sup id="cite_ref-Toots_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toots-178">[178]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonian parliament Riigikogu is elected by citizens over 18 years of age for a four-year term by <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>, and has 101 members. Riigikogu's responsibilities include approval and preservation of the national government, passing legal acts, passing the state budget, and conducting parliamentary supervision. On proposal of <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">the president</a> Riigikogu appoints the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, the chairman of the board of the Bank of Estonia, the Auditor General, the Legal Chancellor, and the Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Forces.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">Government of Estonia</a> is formed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Estonia" title="Prime Minister of Estonia">Prime Minister of Estonia</a> at recommendation of the President, and approved by the Riigikogu. The government, headed by the Prime Minister, represent the political leadership of the country and carry out domestic and foreign policy. Ministers head ministries and represent its interests in the government. Sometimes ministers with no associated ministry are appointed, known as <i>ministers without portfolio</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Estonia has been ruled by coalition governments because no party has been able to obtain an absolute majority in the parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-Toots_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toots-178">[178]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Riigikogu_hoone,_Kaupo_Kalda_foto,_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Toompea Castle pink stucco three-story building with red hip roof" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/220px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/330px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/440px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4600" data-file-height="3448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Riigikogu_hoone,_Kaupo_Kalda_foto,_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The seat of the Parliament of Estonia in <a href="/wiki/Toompea_Castle" title="Toompea Castle">Toompea Castle</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The head of the state is <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">the President</a> who has primarily representative and ceremonial role. The president is elected by the Riigikogu, or by a special electoral college. The President proclaims the laws passed in the Riigikogu, and has right to refuse proclamation and return law in question for a new debate and decision. If Riigikogu passes the law unamended, then the President has right to propose to the Supreme Court to declare the law unconstitutional. The President also represents the country in international relations.<sup id="cite_ref-Toots_178-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toots-178">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">Constitution of Estonia</a> also provides possibility for direct democracy through referendum, although since adoption of the constitution in 1992 the only referendum has been the <a href="/wiki/2003_Estonian_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2003 Estonian European Union membership referendum">referendum on European Union membership</a> in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonia has pursued the development of the <a href="/wiki/E-government" title="E-government">e-government</a>, with 99 percent of the public services being available on the web 24 hours a day.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> In 2005 <a href="/wiki/Electronic_voting_in_Estonia" title="Electronic voting in Estonia">Estonia became</a> the first country in the world to introduce nationwide binding Internet voting in local elections of 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> In 2019 parliamentary elections 44% of the total votes were cast over the internet.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_culture">Political culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Political culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The leader of the <a href="/wiki/Reform_Party_(Estonia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Reform Party (Estonia)">Reform Party</a> <a href="/wiki/Andrus_Ansip" title="Andrus Ansip">Andrus Ansip</a> was the Prime Minister of Estonia since 2005 until 2014. In the end of his nine-year tenure, he was the longest-serving prime minister in the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> In August 2011, <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">President of Estonia</a> <a href="/wiki/Toomas_Hendrik_Ilves" title="Toomas Hendrik Ilves">Toomas Hendrik Ilves</a>, in office since 2006, was re-elected.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> In March 2014, after the resignation of Ansip, <a href="/wiki/Taavi_R%C3%B5ivas" title="Taavi Rõivas">Taavi Rõivas</a> of the Reform Party became new prime minister. 34-year old Rõivas was the youngest prime minister of Europe that time.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> In March 2015, the ruling Reform party, led by Prime Minister Taavi Rõivas, won the <a href="/wiki/2015_Estonian_parliamentary_election" title="2015 Estonian parliamentary election">parliamentary election</a> <sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> In October 2016, Estonian parliament elected <a href="/wiki/Kersti_Kaljulaid" title="Kersti Kaljulaid">Kersti Kaljulaid</a> as the new President of Estonia. She was the first female president of Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> In November 2016, the new chairman of the <a href="/wiki/Centre_Party_(Estonia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre Party (Estonia)">Centre Party</a> <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCri_Ratas" title="Jüri Ratas">Jüri Ratas</a> became the new Prime Minister of Estonia. He succeeded prime minister Rõivas whose government lost a parliamentary vote of no-confidence.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the most recent <a href="/wiki/2019_Estonian_parliamentary_election" title="2019 Estonian parliamentary election">parliamentary elections of 2019</a>, five parties gained seats at Riigikogu. The head of the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Centre_Party" title="Estonian Centre Party">Centre Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCri_Ratas" title="Jüri Ratas">Jüri Ratas</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCri_Ratas%27_second_cabinet" title="Jüri Ratas' second cabinet">formed the government</a> together with <a href="/wiki/Conservative_People%27s_Party_of_Estonia" title="Conservative People's Party of Estonia">Conservative People's Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isamaa" title="Isamaa">Isamaa</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Reform_Party" title="Estonian Reform Party">Reform Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_(Estonia)" title="Social Democratic Party (Estonia)">Social Democratic Party</a> became the opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> On January 13, 2021 Ratas resigned as prime minister in the wake of a corruption scandal.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 26 January, 2021, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Reform_Party" title="Estonian Reform Party">Reform Party</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Kaja_Kallas" title="Kaja Kallas">Kaja Kallas</a> became Estonia's first <a href="/wiki/List_of_elected_and_appointed_female_heads_of_state_and_government" title="List of elected and appointed female heads of state and government">female prime minister</a>, making Estonia the only country in the world to currently be led by both a female President and Prime Minister.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kaja_Kallas%27_cabinet" title="Kaja Kallas' cabinet">new government</a> was a two-party coalition between country's two biggest political parties Reform Party and Centre Party.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Law">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Estonia" title="Law of Estonia">Law of Estonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">Constitution of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">Constitution of Estonia</a> is the fundamental law, establishing the constitutional order based on five principles: human dignity, democracy, rule of law, social state, and the Estonian identity.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> Estonia has a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system based on the Germanic legal model.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> The court system has three-level structure. The first instance are county courts which handle all criminal and civil cases, and administrative courts which hear complaints about government and local officials, and other public disputes. The <a href="/wiki/Appellate_court" title="Appellate court">second instance</a> are district courts which handle appeals about the first instance decisions.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Estonia" title="Supreme Court of Estonia">Supreme Court</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_cassation" title="Court of cassation">court of cassation</a>, and also conducts constitutional review, it has 19 members.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> The judiciary is independent, judges are appointed for life, and can be removed from office only when convicted by court for a criminal deed.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> The Estonian justice system has been rated among the most efficient in the European Union by the EU Justice Scoreboard.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Estonia" title="Foreign relations of Estonia">Foreign relations of Estonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_missions_of_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="Diplomatic missions of Estonia">Diplomatic missions of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn,_Estonia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/220px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/330px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/440px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn,_Estonia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>US President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> giving a speech at the <a href="/wiki/Nordea" title="Nordea">Nordea</a> Concert Hall in <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia was a member of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> from 22 September 1921, and became a member of the United Nations on 17 September 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DFAT_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-204">[204]</a></sup> Since restoration of independence Estonia has pursued close relations with the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western countries</a>, and has been member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> since 29 March 2004, as well as the European Union since 1 May 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-DFAT_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-204">[204]</a></sup> In 2007, Estonia joined the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>, and in 2011 the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DFAT_204-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-204">[204]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eu-Lisa" class="mw-redirect" title="Eu-Lisa">European Union Agency for large-scale IT systems</a> is based in Tallinn, which started operations at the end of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> Estonia held the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">Presidency of the Council of the European Union</a> in the second half of 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the early 1990s, Estonia has been involved in active trilateral <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a> co-operation with Latvia and Lithuania, and Nordic-Baltic co-operation with the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic countries</a>. The Baltic Council is the joint forum of the interparliamentary <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">Baltic Assembly</a> and the intergovernmental Baltic Council of Ministers.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Estonia has built close relationship with the Nordic countries, especially <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>, and is a member of <a href="/wiki/NB8" class="mw-redirect" title="NB8">Nordic-Baltic Eight <i>(NB-8)</i></a> uniting Nordic and Baltic countries.<sup id="cite_ref-DFAT_204-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-204">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NB8_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NB8-208">[208]</a></sup> Joint Nordic-Baltic projects include the education programme Nordplus<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> and mobility programmes for business and industry<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> and for public administration.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council_of_Ministers" title="Nordic Council of Ministers">Nordic Council of Ministers</a> has an office in <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a> with a subsidiaries in <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">Tartu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Narva" title="Narva">Narva</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> The Baltic states are members of <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">Nordic Investment Bank</a>, European Union's <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Battle_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Nordic Battle Group">Nordic Battle Group</a>, and in 2011 were invited to co-operate with <a href="/wiki/NORDEFCO" class="mw-redirect" title="NORDEFCO">NORDEFCO</a> in selected activities.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias,_26.08.2016_(29162818421).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg/220px-P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg/330px-P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg/440px-P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias%2C_26.08.2016_%2829162818421%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:P%C3%B5hjamaade_ja_Balti_riikide_v%C3%A4lisministrite_kohtumine_Riias,_26.08.2016_(29162818421).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Foreign ministers of the Nordic and Baltic countries in <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">Riga</a>, 2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The beginning of the attempt to redefine Estonia as "Nordic" was seen in December 1999, when then Estonian foreign minister (and <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">President of Estonia</a> from 2006 until 2016) <a href="/wiki/Toomas_Hendrik_Ilves" title="Toomas Hendrik Ilves">Toomas Hendrik Ilves</a> delivered a speech entitled "Estonia as a Nordic Country" to the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Institute_for_International_Affairs" title="Swedish Institute for International Affairs">Swedish Institute for International Affairs</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> with potential political calculation behind it being wish to distinguish Estonia from more slowly progressing southern neighbours, which could have postponed early participation in European Union enlargement for Estonia too.<sup id="cite_ref-Mouritzen_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouritzen-219">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andres_Kasekamp" title="Andres Kasekamp">Andres Kasekamp</a> argued in 2005, that relevance of identity discussions in Baltic states decreased with their entrance into EU and NATO together, but predicted, that in the future, attractiveness of Nordic identity in Baltic states will grow and eventually, five Nordic states plus three Baltic states will become a single unit.<sup id="cite_ref-Mouritzen_219-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouritzen-219">[219]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other Estonian international organisation memberships include <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/OSCE" class="mw-redirect" title="OSCE">OSCE</a>, <a href="/wiki/WTO" class="mw-redirect" title="WTO">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="IMF">IMF</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Baltic_Sea_States" title="Council of the Baltic Sea States">Council of the Baltic Sea States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-DFAT_204-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DFAT-204">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> and on 7 June 2019, was elected a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council for a term that begins on 1 January 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-ERR_20190607_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ERR_20190607-222">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Relations with <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> remain generally cold, though there is some practical co-operation.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_Forces" title="Estonian Defence Forces">Estonian Defence Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_League" title="Estonian Defence League">Estonian Defence League</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers,_Trident_Juncture_15_(22200204329).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/220px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/330px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/440px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers,_Trident_Juncture_15_(22200204329).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Estonian soldiers during a NATO exercise in 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_Forces" title="Estonian Defence Forces">Estonian Defence Forces</a> consist of <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Land_Forces" title="Estonian Land Forces">land forces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Navy" title="Estonian Navy">navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Air_Force" title="Estonian Air Force">air force</a>. The current national <a href="/wiki/Military_service" title="Military service">military service</a> is compulsory for healthy men between ages of 18 and 28, with conscripts serving 8 or 11-month tours of duty, depending on their education and position provided by the Defence Forces.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> The peacetime size of the Estonian Defence Forces is about 6,000 persons, with half of those being conscripts. The planned wartime size of the Defence Forces is 60,000 personnel, including 21,000 personnel in high readiness reserve.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> Since 2015 the Estonian defence budget has been over 2% of GDP, fulfilling its NATO defence spending obligation.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_League" title="Estonian Defence League">Estonian Defence League</a> is a voluntary national defence organisation under management of Ministry of Defence. It is organized based on military principles, has its own military equipment, and provides various different military training for its members, including in guerilla tactics. The Defence League has 16,000 members, with additional 10,000 volunteers in its affiliated organisations.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonia co-operates with Latvia and Lithuania in several trilateral Baltic defence co-operation initiatives. As part of Baltic Air Surveillance Network (BALTNET) the three countries manage Baltic airspace control center, Baltic Battalion (BALTBAT) has participated in the <a href="/wiki/NATO_Response_Force" title="NATO Response Force">NATO Response Force</a>, and a joint military educational institution <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Defence_College" title="Baltic Defence College">Baltic Defence College</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">Tartu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Estonian armoured car in desert camouflage Afghanistan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/220px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/330px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/440px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An Estonian <a href="/wiki/Patria_Pasi" title="Patria Pasi">Patria Pasi</a> XA-180 in Afghanistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia joined NATO in 2004. NATO <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_Cyber_Defence_Centre_of_Excellence" title="Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence">Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence</a> was established in Tallinn in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> In response to <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine_(2014%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)">Russian military operations in Ukraine</a>, since 2017 <a href="/wiki/NATO_Enhanced_Forward_Presence" title="NATO Enhanced Forward Presence">NATO Enhanced Forward Presence</a> battalion battle group has been based in <a href="/wiki/Tapa_Army_Base" title="Tapa Army Base">Tapa Army Base</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> Also part of NATO <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Air_Policing" title="Baltic Air Policing">Baltic Air Policing</a> deployment has been based in <a href="/wiki/%C3%84mari_Air_Base" title="Ämari Air Base">Ämari Air Base</a> since 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> In European Union Estonia participates in <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Battlegroup" title="Nordic Battlegroup">Nordic Battlegroup</a> and <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Structured_Cooperation" title="Permanent Structured Cooperation">Permanent Structured Cooperation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 1995 Estonia has participated in numerous international security and peacekeeping missions, including: <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq" title="Multi-National Force – Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">Kosovo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barkhane" title="Operation Barkhane">Mali</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> The peak strength of Estonian deployment in Afghanistan was 289 soldiers in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> 11 Estonian soldiers have been killed in missions of Afghanistan and Iraq.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Estonia" title="Administrative divisions of Estonia">Administrative divisions of Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">Counties of Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Estonia" title="Municipalities of Estonia">Municipalities of Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="Boroughs of Estonia">Boroughs of Estonia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Populated_places_in_Estonia" title="Populated places in Estonia">Populated places in Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg/310px-Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="205" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg/465px-Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg/620px-Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1591" data-file-height="1051"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Estonian_administrative_divisions_2017_with_labels.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Municipalities of Estonia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia is a unitary country with a single-tier local government system. Local affairs are managed autonomously by local governments. Since administrative reform in 2017, there are in total 79 local governments, including 15 towns and 64 rural municipalities. All municipalities have equal legal status and form part of a <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">county</a>, which is a state administrative unit.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> Representative body of local authorities is municipal council, elected at general direct elections for a four-year term. The council appoints local government, headed by a mayor. For additional decentralization the local authorities may form municipal districts with limited authority, currently those have been formed in <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">Hiiumaa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rahandusmin_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rahandusmin-239">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Separately from administrative units there are also <a href="/wiki/Populated_places_in_Estonia" title="Populated places in Estonia">settlement units</a>: village, small borough, borough, and town. Generally, villages have less than 300, small boroughs have between 300 and 1000, boroughs and towns have over 1000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-rahandusmin_239-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rahandusmin-239">[239]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Estonia" title="Economy of Estonia">Economy of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="image"><img alt="map of European Union eurozone" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/220px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/330px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/440px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="645" data-file-height="690"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Estonia is part of a monetary union, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> (dark blue), and of the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal Market (European Union)">EU single market</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a member of the European Union, Estonia is considered a high-income economy by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">GDP (PPP) per capita</a> of the country was $29,312 in 2016 according to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-8">[8]</a></sup> Because of its rapid growth, Estonia has often been described as a <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Tiger" title="Baltic Tiger">Baltic Tiger</a> beside Lithuania and Latvia. Beginning 1 January 2011, Estonia adopted the euro and became the 17th <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> member state.<sup id="cite_ref-euroreuters_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euroreuters-240">[240]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, Estonia had the lowest ratio of government debt to GDP among EU countries at 6.7% at the end of 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> A balanced budget, almost non-existent <a href="/wiki/Public_debt" class="mw-redirect" title="Public debt">public debt</a>, flat-rate income tax, free trade regime, competitive commercial banking sector, innovative <a href="/wiki/E-Services" class="mw-redirect" title="E-Services">e-Services</a> and even mobile-based services are all hallmarks of Estonia's market economy. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tln1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="aerial view of high rises at sunset" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/220px-Tln1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/330px-Tln1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/440px-Tln1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5473" data-file-height="3655"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tln1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The central business district of <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia produces about 75% of its consumed electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> In 2011, about 85% of it was generated with locally mined <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale" title="Oil shale">oil shale</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> Alternative energy sources such as wood, peat, and biomass make up approximately 9% of primary energy production. Renewable wind energy was about 6% of total consumption in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> Estonia imports <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> products from western Europe and Russia. Estonia imports 100% of its <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">natural gas from Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> Oil shale energy, telecommunications, textiles, chemical products, banking, services, food and fishing, timber, shipbuilding, electronics, and transportation are key sectors of the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ice-free_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice-free port">ice-free port</a> of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Muuga" class="mw-redirect" title="Port of Muuga">Muuga</a>, near Tallinn, is a modern facility featuring good transshipment capability, a high-capacity grain elevator, chill/frozen storage, and new oil tanker off-loading capabilities.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The railroad serves as a conduit between the West, Russia, and other points.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Because of the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932010" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2010">global economic recession that began in 2007</a>, the GDP of Estonia decreased by 1.4% in the 2nd quarter of 2008, over 3% in the 3rd quarter of 2008, and over 9% in the 4th quarter of 2008. The Estonian government made a supplementary negative budget, which was passed by <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">Riigikogu</a>. The revenue of the budget was decreased for 2008 by EEK 6.1&nbsp;billion and the expenditure by EEK 3.2&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> In 2010, the economic situation stabilised and started a growth based on strong exports. In the fourth quarter of 2010, Estonian industrial output increased by 23% compared to the year before. The country has been experiencing economic growth ever since.<sup id="cite_ref-Stat_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stat-248">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to Eurostat data, Estonian PPS GDP per capita stood at 67% of the EU average in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> In 2017, the average monthly gross salary in Estonia was €1221.<sup id="cite_ref-StatisticsEstonia_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StatisticsEstonia-250">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>However, there are vast disparities in GDP between different areas of Estonia; currently, over half of the country's GDP is created in Tallinn.<sup id="cite_ref-BBN_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBN-251">[251]</a></sup> In 2008, the GDP per capita of Tallinn stood at 172% of the Estonian average,<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-252">[252]</a></sup> which makes the per capita GDP of Tallinn as high as 115% of the European Union average, exceeding the average levels of other counties. </p>
      <p>The unemployment rate in March 2016 was 6.4%, which is below the EU average,<sup id="cite_ref-StatisticsEstonia_250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StatisticsEstonia-250">[250]</a></sup> while real GDP growth in 2011 was 8.0%,<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_Estonia_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics_Estonia-253">[253]</a></sup> five times the euro-zone average. In 2012, Estonia remained the only euro member with a budget surplus, and with a national debt of only 6%, it is one of the least indebted countries in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_indicators">Economic indicators</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Economic indicators">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Estonia's economy continues to benefit from a transparent government and policies that sustain a high level of <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">economic freedom</a>, ranking 6th globally and 2nd in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> The rule of <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Estonia" title="Law of Estonia">law</a> remains strongly buttressed and enforced by an independent and efficient judicial system. A simplified tax system with flat rates and low indirect taxation, openness to foreign investment, and a liberal trade regime have supported the resilient and well-functioning economy.<sup id="cite_ref-taxfoundation1_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taxfoundation1-257">[257]</a></sup> As of May&nbsp;2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the <a href="/wiki/Ease_of_Doing_Business_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Ease of Doing Business Index">Ease of Doing Business Index</a> by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank Group</a> places the country 16th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> The strong focus on the IT sector has led to much faster, simpler and efficient public services where for example filing a tax return takes less than five minutes and 98% of banking transactions are conducted through the internet.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> Estonia has the third lowest business bribery risk in the world, according to TRACE Matrix.<sup id="cite_ref-traceinternational.org_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-traceinternational.org-261">[261]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="BarChartTemplate" style="border-style:solid; border-width:1px; border-color:#c0c0c0; background-color:#fdfdfd; text-align:left; float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0;" cellpadding="1">
