      <p>Estonia is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with an advanced, <a href="/wiki/High-income_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="High-income economy">high-income economy</a> that was among the fastest-growing in the EU since its entry in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> The country ranks very high in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-HDI_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-10">[10]</a></sup> and compares well in measures of <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">economic freedom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World_(report)" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom in the World (report)">civil liberties</a>, education,<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">press freedom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup> Estonian citizens receive <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free education</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> and the longest paid <a href="/wiki/Maternity_leave" class="mw-redirect" title="Maternity leave">maternity leave</a> in the OECD.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup> One of the world's most digitally-advanced societies,<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> in 2005 Estonia became the first state to hold elections over the <a href="/wiki/Electronic_voting_in_Estonia" title="Electronic voting in Estonia">Internet</a>, and in 2014, the first state to provide <a href="/wiki/E-residency_of_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="E-residency of Estonia">e-residency</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historic_development">Historic development</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Historic development">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In 1928, a stable currency, the <i><a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">kroon</a></i>, was established. It is issued by the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Estonia" title="Bank of Estonia">Bank of Estonia</a>, the country's <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a>. The word <i>kroon</i> (<small>Estonian pronunciation:&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Estonian" title="Help:IPA/Estonian">[ˈkroːn]</a></span>, "crown") is related to that of the other <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic</a> currencies (such as the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_krona" title="Swedish krona">Swedish krona</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Danish_krone" title="Danish krone">Danish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_krone" title="Norwegian krone">Norwegian krone</a>). The kroon succeeded the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_mark" title="Estonian mark">mark</a> in 1928 and was used until 1940. After Estonia regained its independence, the kroon was reintroduced in 1992. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia,_2002-2012.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/220px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="115" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/330px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/440px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="354"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia,_2002-2012.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Estonia's GDP growth from 2000 till 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia#Regaining_independence" title="History of Estonia">re-establishing independence</a>, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia's market reforms put it among the economic leaders in the former <a href="/wiki/COMECON" class="mw-redirect" title="COMECON">COMECON</a> area.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In 1994, based on the economic theories of <a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">Milton Friedman</a>, Estonia became one of the first countries to adopt a <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">flat tax</a>, with a uniform rate of 26% regardless of personal income. This rate has since been reduced three times, to 24% in January 2005, 23% in January 2006, and most recently to 21% by January 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">Government of Estonia</a> finalised the design of <a href="/wiki/Estonian_euro_coins" title="Estonian euro coins">Estonian euro coins</a> in late 2004, and adopted the euro as the country's currency on 1 January 2011, later than planned due to continued high inflation.<sup id="cite_ref-euroreuters_240-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euroreuters-240">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-euro-EFP_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euro-EFP-271">[270]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Land_Value_Tax" class="mw-redirect" title="Land Value Tax">Land Value Tax</a> is levied which is used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, however 100% of the revenue is used to fund Local Councils. The rate is set by the Local Council within the limits of 0.1–2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-272">[271]</a></sup> The Land Value Tax is levied on the value of the land only with improvements and buildings not considered. Very few exemptions are considered on the land value tax and even public institutions are subject to the tax.<sup id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-272">[271]</a></sup> The tax has contributed to a high rate (~90%)<sup id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_272-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-272">[271]</a></sup> of owner-occupied residences within Estonia, compared to a rate of 67.4% in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1999, Estonia experienced its worst year economically since it regained independence in 1991, largely because of the impact of the <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">1998 Russian financial crisis</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Estonia joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> in November 1999. With assistance from the European Union, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">Nordic Investment Bank</a>, Estonia completed most of its preparations for European Union membership by the end of 2002 and now has one of the strongest economies of the new member states of the European Union.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Estonia joined the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Estonia" title="Transport in Estonia">Transport in Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg/220px-Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg/330px-Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg/440px-Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tallinn_Airport_03_July_2006.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Airport" title="Tallinn Airport">Tallinn Airport</a> in 2006
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tallinn" title="Port of Tallinn">Port of Tallinn</a>, taking into account both cargo and passenger traffic, is one of the largest port enterprises of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. In 2018, the enterprise was listed in <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Stock_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Tallinn Stock Exchange">Tallinn Stock Exchange</a>. It was the first time in nearly 20 years in Estonia when a state-owned company went public in Estonia. It was also the 2nd largest <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">IPO</a> in Nasdaq Tallinn in the number of retail investors participating. The Republic of Estonia remains as the largest shareholder and holds 67% of the company.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Owned by <a href="/wiki/Eesti_Raudtee" title="Eesti Raudtee">AS Eesti Raudtee</a>, there are many significant <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Estonia" title="Rail transport in Estonia">railroad connections in Estonia</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Tallinn%E2%80%93Narva_railway" title="Tallinn–Narva railway">Tallinn–Narva railway</a>, which is 209.6&nbsp;km (130.2&nbsp;mi) long main connection to <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Petersburg">St. Petersburg</a>. The most important <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Estonia" title="Highways in Estonia">highways in Estonia</a>, in other hand, includes <a href="/wiki/Narva_Highway" class="mw-redirect" title="Narva Highway">Narva Highway</a> (<a href="/wiki/European_route_E20" title="European route E20">E20</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tartu_Highway" class="mw-redirect" title="Tartu Highway">Tartu Highway</a> (<a href="/wiki/European_route_E263" title="European route E263">E263</a>) and <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu_Highway" class="mw-redirect" title="Pärnu Highway">Pärnu Highway</a> (<a href="/wiki/European_route_E67" title="European route E67">E67</a>). </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Lennart_Meri_Tallinn_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Lennart Meri Tallinn Airport">Lennart Meri Tallinn Airport</a> in Tallinn is the largest airport in Estonia and serves as a <a href="/wiki/Airline_hub" title="Airline hub">hub</a> for the national airline <a href="/wiki/Nordica_(airline)" title="Nordica (airline)">Nordica</a>, as well as the secondary hub for <a href="/wiki/AirBaltic" title="AirBaltic">AirBaltic</a><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines" title="LOT Polish Airlines">LOT Polish Airlines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> Total passengers using the airport has increased on average by 14.2% annually since 1998. On 16 November 2012 Tallinn Airport has reached two million passenger landmark for the first time in its history.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resources">Resources</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Resources">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Estonian_shale.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/220px-Estonian_shale.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/330px-Estonian_shale.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/440px-Estonian_shale.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4912" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Estonian_shale.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_in_Estonia" title="Oil shale in Estonia">oil shale industry</a> in Estonia is one of the most developed in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-iea_20_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iea_20-279">[278]</a></sup> In 2012, oil shale supplied 70% of Estonia's <a href="/wiki/Total_primary_energy_supply" class="mw-redirect" title="Total primary energy supply">total primary energy</a> and accounted for 4% of Estonia's gross domestic product.<sup id="cite_ref-audit_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-audit-280">[279]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iea_7_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iea_7-281">[280]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Although Estonia is in general resource-poor, the land still offers a large variety of smaller resources. The country has large <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale" title="Oil shale">oil shale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> deposits, along with forests that cover 48% of the land.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> In addition to oil shale and limestone, Estonia also has large reserves of <a href="/wiki/Phosphorite" title="Phosphorite">phosphorite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uraninite" title="Uraninite">pitchblende</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> that currently are not mined, or not mined extensively.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Significant quantities of <a href="/wiki/Rare-earth" class="mw-redirect" title="Rare-earth">rare-earth</a> oxides are found in tailings accumulated from 50 years of <a href="/wiki/Uranium_ore" title="Uranium ore">uranium ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shale" title="Shale">shale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Loparite" class="mw-redirect" title="Loparite">loparite</a> mining at <a href="/wiki/Sillam%C3%A4e" title="Sillamäe">Sillamäe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> Because of the rising prices of rare earths, extraction of these oxides has become economically viable. The country currently exports around 3000 tonnes per annum, representing around 2% of world production.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2008, public debate has discussed whether Estonia should build a nuclear power plant to secure energy production after closure of old units in the <a href="/wiki/Narva_Power_Plants" title="Narva Power Plants">Narva Power Plants</a>, if they are not reconstructed by the year 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry_and_environment">Industry and environment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Industry and environment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_in_Estonia" title="Oil shale in Estonia">Oil shale in Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Narva_Power_Plants" title="Narva Power Plants">Narva Power Plants</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_Estonia" title="Wind power in Estonia">Wind power in Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Rõuste wind turbines next to wetland" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/220px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/330px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/440px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Rõuste wind farm in <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A4%C3%A4neranna_Parish" title="Lääneranna Parish">Lääneranna Parish</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Food, construction, and electronic industries are currently among the most important branches of Estonia's industry.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In 2007, the construction industry employed more than 80,000 people, around 12% of the entire country's workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup> Another important industrial sector is the machinery and chemical industry, which is mainly located in <a href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" title="Ida-Viru County">Ida-Viru County</a> and around Tallinn. </p>
      <p>The oil shale-based <a href="/wiki/Mining_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Mining industry">mining industry</a>, also concentrated in <a href="/wiki/Virumaa" title="Virumaa">East Estonia</a>, produces around 90% of the entire country's electricity.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Although the amount of pollutants emitted has been falling since the 1980s,<sup id="cite_ref-Auer_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Auer-289">[288]</a></sup> the air is still contaminated with <a href="/wiki/Sulphur_dioxide" class="mw-redirect" title="Sulphur dioxide">sulphur dioxide</a> from the mining industry the Soviet Union rapidly developed in the early 1950s. In some areas, coastal seawater is polluted, mainly around the <a href="/wiki/Sillam%C3%A4e" title="Sillamäe">Sillamäe</a> industrial complex.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonia is dependent on other countries for energy. In recent years, many local and foreign companies have been investing in renewable energy sources.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Wind power has been increasing steadily in Estonia and the total current amount of energy produced from wind is nearly 60 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MW</a>; another roughly 399&nbsp;MW worth of projects are currently being developed and more than 2800&nbsp;MW being proposed in the <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">Lake Peipus</a> area and coastal areas of <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">Hiiumaa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Currently<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (February 2011)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup>, there are plans to renovate some older units of the Narva Power Plants, establish new power stations, and provide higher efficiency in oil shale-based energy production.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> Estonia <a href="/wiki/Liberalization" title="Liberalization">liberalised</a> 35% of its electricity market in April 2010; the electricity market as whole was to be liberalised by 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Together with Lithuania, Poland, and Latvia, the country considered participating in constructing the <a href="/wiki/Visaginas_nuclear_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Visaginas nuclear power plant">Visaginas nuclear power plant</a> in Lithuania to replace the <a href="/wiki/Ignalina_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant">Ignalina</a> nuclear plant.<sup id="cite_ref-wnn-lt_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wnn-lt-296">[295]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-le_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-le-297">[296]</a></sup> However, due to the slow pace of the project and problems with the nuclear sector (like the <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">Fukushima disaster</a> and bad example of <a href="/wiki/Olkiluoto_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant">Olkiluoto plant</a>), <a href="/wiki/Eesti_Energia" title="Eesti Energia">Eesti Energia</a> shifted its main focus to <a href="/wiki/Shale_oil" title="Shale oil">shale oil</a> production, seen as far more profitable.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Estonian electricity network forms a part of the <a href="/wiki/Nord_Pool_Spot" class="mw-redirect" title="Nord Pool Spot">Nord Pool Spot</a> network.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonia has a strong information technology <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Quaternary sector of the economy">sector</a>, partly owing to the <a href="/wiki/Tiigrih%C3%BCpe" title="Tiigrihüpe">Tiigrihüpe</a> project undertaken in the mid-1990s, and has been mentioned as the most "wired" and advanced country in Europe in the terms of e-Government of Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup> The 2014 <a href="/wiki/E-residency_of_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="E-residency of Estonia">e-residency program</a> began offering those services to non-residents in Estonia. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Skype" title="Skype">Skype</a> was written by Estonia-based developers <a href="/wiki/Ahti_Heinla" title="Ahti Heinla">Ahti Heinla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Priit_Kasesalu" title="Priit Kasesalu">Priit Kasesalu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Tallinn" title="Jaan Tallinn">Jaan Tallinn</a>, who had also originally developed <a href="/wiki/Kazaa" title="Kazaa">Kazaa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> Other notable tech <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startups</a> include <a href="/wiki/GrabCAD" title="GrabCAD">GrabCAD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortumo" title="Fortumo">Fortumo</a> and <a href="/wiki/TransferWise" class="mw-redirect" title="TransferWise">TransferWise</a>. It has been claimed that Estonia has the most startups per person in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">Trade</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Trade">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Stock_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Tallinn Stock Exchange">Tallinn Stock Exchange</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg" class="image"><img alt="graph of exports in 2010 showing $10,345,000,000 2.8 percent cars, 12 percent lubricating oil, 3.8 percent telephone" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/280px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="280" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/420px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/560px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Graphical depiction of Estonia's product exports in 28 colour-coded categories
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Estonia has had a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> since the end of the 1990s and one of the highest per capita income levels in Eastern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> Proximity to the Scandinavian and Finnish markets, its location between the East and West, competitive cost structure and a highly skilled labour force have been the major Estonian comparative advantages in the beginning of the 2000s (decade). As the largest city, Tallinn has emerged as a <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Stock_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Tallinn Stock Exchange">Tallinn Stock Exchange</a> joined recently with the <a href="/wiki/OMX" class="mw-redirect" title="OMX">OMX</a> system. Several cryptocurrency trading platforms are officially recognised by the government, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=CoinMetro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CoinMetro (page does not exist)">CoinMetro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> The current government has pursued tight <a href="/wiki/Finance" title="Finance">fiscal</a> policies, resulting in balanced budgets and low <a href="/wiki/Public_debt" class="mw-redirect" title="Public debt">public debt</a>. </p>
      <p>In 2007, however, a large current account deficit and rising inflation put pressure on <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">Estonia's currency</a>, which was pegged to the Euro, highlighting the need for growth in export-generating industries. Estonia exports mainly machinery and equipment, wood and paper, textiles, food products, furniture, and metals and chemical products.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAworld_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-305">[304]</a></sup> Estonia also exports 1.562&nbsp;billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAworld_305-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-305">[304]</a></sup> At the same time Estonia imports machinery and equipment, chemical products, textiles, food products and transportation equipment.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAworld_305-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-305">[304]</a></sup> Estonia imports 200&nbsp;million kilowatt hours of electricity annually.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAworld_305-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-305">[304]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 2007 and 2013, Estonia received 53.3&nbsp;billion <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">kroons</a> (3.4&nbsp;billion euros) from various European Union Structural Funds as direct supports, creating the largest foreign investments into Estonia.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> Majority of the European Union financial aid will be invested into the following fields: energy economies, entrepreneurship, administrative capability, education, information society, environment protection, regional and local development, research and development activities, healthcare and welfare, transportation and labour market.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> Main sources of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investments</a> to Estonia are Sweden and Finland (As of 31&nbsp;December&nbsp;2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 48.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Estonia" title="Demographics of Estonia">Demographics of Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:none">

          </tr>

          </tr>

           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.9%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Finns" title="Finns">Finns</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Latvians" title="Latvians">Latvians</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.2%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.2%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:2.0%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.0%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Unknown</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:1.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png" class="image"><img alt="The population of Estonia, from 1960 to 2019, with a peak in 1990." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png/280px-Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="178" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png/420px-Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="349"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Eesti_rahvaarv_1960-2019.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population of Estonia 1960–2019. The changes are largely attributed to Soviet immigration and emigration.<sup id="cite_ref-stat.ee_2_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stat.ee_2-310">[309]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Before World War II, ethnic <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">Estonians</a> made up 88% of the population, with national minorities constituting the remaining 12%.<sup id="cite_ref-ethnic_minor_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnic_minor-311">[310]</a></sup> The largest minority groups in 1934 were <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">Germans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swedish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Swedish people">Swedes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvians" title="Latvians">Latvians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jewish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish people">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finns" title="Finns">Finns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Izhorians" title="Izhorians">Ingrians</a>. </p>
      <p>The share of <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Germans" title="Baltic Germans">Baltic Germans</a> in Estonia had fallen from 5.3% (~46,700) in 1881 to 1.3% (16,346) by 1934,<sup id="cite_ref-ethnic_minor_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnic_minor-311">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-baltic_germans_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baltic_germans-312">[311]</a></sup> mainly due to emigration to Germany in the light of general Russification at the end of the 19th century<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and the independence of Estonia in the 20th century. </p>
      <p>Between 1945 and 1989, the share of ethnic Estonians in the population resident within the currently defined boundaries of Estonia dropped to 61%, caused primarily by the Soviet programme promoting mass immigration of urban industrial workers from Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus, as well as by wartime emigration and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>'s mass deportations and executions.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> By 1989, minorities constituted more than one-third of the population, as the number of non-Estonians had grown almost fivefold. </p>
      <p>At the end of the 1980s, Estonians<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (May 2020)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> perceived their demographic change as a <a href="/wiki/Disaster" title="Disaster">national catastrophe</a>. This was a result of the <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migration</a> policies essential to the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Estonian SSR">Soviet Nationalisation Programme</a> aiming to <a href="/wiki/Russify" class="mw-redirect" title="Russify">russify</a> Estonia – administrative and military immigration of non-Estonians from the USSR coupled with the deportation of Estonians to the USSR.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In the decade after the reconstitution of independence, large-scale emigration by ethnic Russians and the removal of the Russian military bases in 1994 caused<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> the proportion of ethnic Estonians in Estonia to increase from 61% to 69% in 2006. </p>
      <p>Modern Estonia is a fairly ethnically heterogeneous country, but this heterogeneity is not a feature of much of the country as the non-Estonian population is concentrated in two of Estonia's counties. Thirteen of Estonia's 15 counties are over 80% ethnic Estonian, the most homogeneous being <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">Hiiumaa</a>, where Estonians account for 98.4% of the population. In the counties of <a href="/wiki/Harju_County" title="Harju County">Harju</a> (including the capital city, <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" title="Ida-Viru County">Ida-Viru</a>, however, ethnic Estonians make up 60% and 20% of the population, respectively. <a href="/wiki/History_of_Russians_in_Estonia" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Russians in Estonia">Russians</a> make up 25.6% of the total population but account for 36% of the population in Harju county and 70% of the population in Ida-Viru county. </p>
      <p>The Estonian Cultural Autonomy law that was passed in 1925 was unique in Europe at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> Cultural autonomies could be granted to <a href="/wiki/Minorities" class="mw-redirect" title="Minorities">minorities</a> numbering more than 3,000 people with longstanding ties to the Republic of Estonia. Before the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Estonian SSR">Soviet occupation</a>, the Germans and Jewish minorities managed to elect a cultural council. The Law on Cultural Autonomy for National Minorities was reinstated in 1993. Historically, large parts of Estonia's northwestern coast and islands have been populated by indigenous ethnically <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Swedes" title="Estonian Swedes">Rannarootslased</a> (Coastal Swedes). </p>
      <p>In recent years the number of Coastal Swedes has risen again, numbering in 2008 almost 500 people, owing to the property reforms in the beginning of the 1990s. In 2004, the <a href="/wiki/Ingrian_Finnish" class="mw-redirect" title="Ingrian Finnish">Ingrian Finnish</a> minority in Estonia elected a cultural council and was granted cultural autonomy. The <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Swedes" title="Estonian Swedes">Estonian Swedish</a> minority similarly received cultural autonomy in 2007. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Society">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Estonia" title="Human rights in Estonia">Human rights in Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nordic_identity_in_Estonia" title="Nordic identity in Estonia">Nordic identity in Estonia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Estonian_alien%27s_passport" title="Estonian alien's passport">Estonian alien's passport</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/220px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/330px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/440px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1515"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Estonian folk dancers
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><br> </p>
      <p>Estonian society has undergone considerable changes over the last twenty years, one of the most notable being the increasing level of stratification, and the distribution of family income. The <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a> has held steadily higher than the European Union average (31 in 2009),<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup> although it has clearly dropped. The registered unemployment rate in January 2012 was 7.7%.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern Estonia is a multinational country in which 109 languages are spoken, according to a 2000 census. 67.3% of Estonian citizens speak <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a> as their native language, 29.7% Russian, and 3% speak other languages.<sup id="cite_ref-PopulationByNationality_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopulationByNationality-316">[315]</a></sup> As of 2&nbsp;July&nbsp;2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 84.1% of Estonian residents are Estonian citizens, 8.6% are citizens of other countries and 7.3% are "citizens with undetermined citizenship".<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> Since 1992, roughly 140,000 people have acquired Estonian citizenship by passing <a href="/wiki/Naturalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Naturalisation">naturalisation</a> exams.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> Estonia has also accepted <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis#Relocation_and_resettlement_of_asylum_seekers" title="European migrant crisis">quota refugees</a> under the migrant plan agreed upon by EU member states in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[318]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ethnic distribution in Estonia is very homogeneous at a county level; in most counties, over 90% of residents are ethnic <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">Estonians</a>. In contrast, in large urban centres like <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">Tallinn</a>, Estonians account for 60% of the population and the remainder is mostly composed of Russian and other Slavic inhabitants, who arrived in Estonia during the Soviet period.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG/220px-Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG/330px-Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG/440px-Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saare_k%C3%BCla_Piirissaar.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Estonia" title="Russians in Estonia">Russian</a> <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believer</a> village with a church on <a href="/wiki/Piirissaar" title="Piirissaar">Piirissaar</a> island
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The 2008 <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">United Nations Human Rights Council</a> report called "extremely credible" the description of the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_nationality_law" title="Estonian nationality law">citizenship policy of Estonia</a> as "discriminatory".<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> According to surveys, only 5% of the Russian community have considered returning to Russia in the near future. Estonian Russians have developed their own identity – more than half of the respondents recognised that Estonian Russians differ noticeably from the Russians in Russia. When compared with results from a 2000 survey, Russians had a more positive attitude toward the future.<sup id="cite_ref-Societal_survey_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Societal_survey-321">[320]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Estonia was the first post-Soviet republic to legalise civil unions for same-sex couples, with a law approved in October 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup> Political disagreements delayed adoption of the necessary implementing legislation, and same-sex couples were not able to sign <a href="/wiki/Recognition_of_same-sex_unions_in_Estonia" title="Recognition of same-sex unions in Estonia">cohabitation agreements</a> until January 1, 2016. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Urbanization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Estonia" title="List of cities and towns in Estonia">List of cities and towns in Estonia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Tallinn is the capital and the largest city of Estonia, and lies on the northern coast of Estonia, along the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland" title="Gulf of Finland">Gulf of Finland</a>. There are 33 cities and several town-parish towns in the country. In total, there are 47 <i>linn</i>a, with "linn" in English meaning both "cities" and "towns". More than 70% of the population lives in towns. </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Estonia" title="Religion in Estonia">Religion in Estonia</a>
